channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Frats Are Being Frats’: Greek Life Is Stoking the Virus on Some Campuses
item.description: Universities are struggling with how to prevent tightly packed sorority and fraternity houses from turning into virus clusters.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon, Frances Robles, Alan Blinder and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: At least 165 of the 290 coronavirus cases at the University of Washington’s Seattle campus have been associated with its Greek Row.

item.title: Sturgis Motorcycle Rally Rolls to a Close as Virus Tracking Remains Complex
item.description: The annual rally in Sturgis, S.D., drew hundreds of thousands of people. It will be challenging to track any coronavirus outbreak as bikers return to their home states.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors on Main Street during the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally in South Dakota.

item.title: U.N.C. at Chapel Hill to Move Online as Coronavirus Spreads
item.description: The university chose to abandon in-person instruction for undergraduates after at least 177 students tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will move all of its undergraduate classes online starting Wednesday.

item.title: Why Pooled Testing for the Coronavirus Isn't Working in the U.S.
item.description: Combining samples for coronavirus testing, an approach once hailed by U.S. health officials, only works when the vast majority of tests are negative.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Coronavirus diagnostic testing with a Roche machine in Sydney, Australia. Routinely used in many countries, pooled testing has been slow to catch on in the United States.

item.title: Abortion Fight Evolves, Overshadowed in 2020 but With Huge Stakes
item.description: Anti-abortion groups hope to keep Americans voting Republican despite anger at leaders’ handling of the coronavirus, race and the economy. Abortion-rights groups say the issues are all linked.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Sally Ryan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canvassers for the Susan B. Anthony List, a prominent anti-abortion group, on their way to encourage voters to support candidates who oppose abortion.

item.title: Ady Barkan, Activist and DNC Speaker, on Biden and 'Medicare for All'
item.description: After learning in 2016 that he had a terminal neurodegenerative disease, Mr. Barkan became a champion of “Medicare for all.” He spoke with The Times ahead of his speech on Tuesday night at the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ady Barkan, an activist and lawyer who has A.L.S., is one of the few progressives to have a speaking spot at the Democratic National Convention this week.

item.title: Christie calls Kasich a ‘backstabber’ and tells Democrats ‘you can have him.’
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: The N.R.A. and Wayne LaPierre’s Next Foe: One of Their Own
item.description: As New York’s attorney general moves to dissolve the gun group, a former top executive is releasing a tell-all about how the N.R.A. is “rife with fraud and corruption.”
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim
item.media:description: Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A.’s longtime leader. A former executive at the gun group is releasing a tell-all book about what he calls Mr. LaPierre’s “evil circus.”

item.title: Eric Holder condemns Trump’s efforts to impede mail-in voting.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Why the DNC Has 17 Keynote Speakers Instead of One
item.description: Democrats have assembled a mash-up of 17 of the “next generation of party leaders,” instead of one featured speaker. But are they missing an opportunity to showcase the next Barack Obama?
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: When Barack Obama spoke at the Democratic National Convention in 2004 he was just an Illinois state senator running for the U.S. Senate.

item.title: 10 Months After New Orleans Hotel Collapse, Third Body Recovered From Rubble
item.description: The body of Jose Ponce Arreola, a 63-year-old construction worker, was recovered almost a year after a Hard Rock Hotel under construction collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: The partial collapse of the planned Hard Rock Hotel in New Orleans in 2019. In January, a red tarp flew off the rubble, revealing the dangling legs of a corpse.

item.title: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, will testify before the Senate on Friday about service cuts.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, called a halt to service cuts that critics said had imperiled mail-in voting.

item.title: Trump Pardons Susan B. Anthony
item.description: President Trump’s pardon of the famed suffragist came as women celebrated the 100th anniversary of their right to vote, and in the middle of his attacks on the prospect of mail-in voting.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Frances Benjamin Johnston, via Library of Congress
item.media:description: Susan B. Anthony in 1900. She was tried for illegally voting and protested her $100 fine.

item.title: Millions of Californians Could Lose Power During Rolling Blackouts
item.description: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom demanded an investigation into rolling blackouts over the weekend. Also: The Democratic National Convention kicked off.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A man under high tension power lines at a dog park in Redondo Beach on Sunday.

item.title: Final Report on Russian Interference and Ties to Trump Is Released by G.O.P.-Led Senate Panel
item.description: A nearly 1,000-page report confirmed the special counsel’s findings at a moment when President Trump’s allies have sought to undermine that inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Group of 20 summit in Japan last year.

item.title: Who spoke most on the first night of the convention?
item.dc:creator: Weiyi Cai and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio was one of four Republicans who spoke in support of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday.

item.title: Michelle and Bernie Speak Their Truth
item.description: They approach politics from two very different perspectives, but they arrived at the same conclusion Monday night.

item.title: A Century of Suffrage
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick

item.title: As Amenities Sit Unused, Airports Reconsider Their Design
item.description: Airports have some of the most lucrative square footage in the world, but the pandemic has crushed that calculus.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Williams
item.media:description: The Apple Store at Changi Airport closed in March. With more than 400 shops, the airport would be the fourth-largest mall by the number of tenants if it were in the United States.

item.title: Covid-19 Cases and Deaths: Live News Updates
item.description: Bill de Blasio is the only big-city mayor planning some in-person learning for students. The Democratic National Convention opened with searing criticism of President Trump’s handling of the pandemic.

item.title: Uber and Lyft Consider Franchise-Like Model in California
item.description: Under pressure to classify their freelance drivers as employees, the ride-hailing companies are discussing another option.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uber and Lyft have separately discussed plans to license their technology to those who want to operate fleets of ride-hailing cars in California.

item.title: Watch Four Moments That Mattered on the First Night of the D.N.C.
item.description: Two of our correspondents break down highlights from the Democrats’ first virtual convention.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: Eva Longoria introduces the start of the 2020 Democratic National Convention on Monday.

item.title: Bill Clinton to Speak at Night 2 of the Democratic National Convention
item.description: When the former president speaks on Tuesday, it will be the first Democratic convention since the 1980s where he will be little more than a bystander, as the party he once led to the political center shifts steadily to the left.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill Clinton energized Democrats with a 48-minute speech at the party’s 2012 convention in Charlotte, N.C.

item.title: A Novel Way to Combat Covid-19 in Nursing Homes: Strike Teams
item.description: Borrowing from a model used for natural disasters, states are sending teams of responders to help facilities with outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Critchfield
item.media:credit: Shawn Poynter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a Buncombe County, N.C., coronavirus strike team met before heading to a nursing home facility this month.

item.title: Highlights From the Democratic National Convention: Night 1
item.description: On the first night of their first virtual convention, Democrats made their case for Joseph R. Biden Jr. with a mix of recorded programming and notable speakers delivering live remarks.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: America Has Two Feet. It’s About to Lose One of Them.
item.description: For decades, U.S. metrologists have juggled two conflicting measurements for the foot. Henceforth, only one shall rule.
item.dc:creator: Alanna Mitchell
item.category: National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:description: U.S. Geological Surveyors measuring a baseline near Fort Wingate, N.M., in 1883.

item.title: The Biggest Moments From Night 1 of the Democratic Convention
item.description: Michelle Obama’s voting plea, Bernie Sanders’s call to circle around Joe Biden and a moment of silence for George Floyd: The virtual gathering was surreal, but still powerful at times.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Schedule of DNC: Speakers List, Streaming, Start Time and More
item.description: Jill Biden and Bill Clinton are headlining the second night of the convention on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Representative Gwen Moore of Wisconsin speaking in Milwaukee on the first day of the Democratic convention. Most speakers throughout the week are appearing virtually from around the country.

item.title: Michelle Obama Calls Trump ‘Wrong President for Our Country,’ Urging Voters to Act
item.description: Speaking in deeply personal terms, the former first lady says the country has been living with the failures of a president who is not up to the task.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

item.title: A most unusual convention is now underway.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:description: A Zoom grid showed people across the country reacting to Michelle Obama’s convention speech.

item.title: Full Michelle Obama D.N.C. Speech Transcript
item.description: Michelle Obama, the former first lady, was the keynote speaker on the first night of the 2020 Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: Bernie Sanders Goes on Attack Against Trump and Urges Support for Biden
item.description: In a prime-time speech at the Democratic National Convention, the runner-up for the party’s nomination assailed President Trump, warning, “The future of our democracy is at stake.”
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders and his backers have, for the most part, been willing to accept if not embrace Joseph R. Biden Jr. and band together to oust President Trump,

item.title: Coronavirus Strikes Mink in Utah
item.description: Five animals on two farms test positive, but many more are believed to be affected.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: Humane Society of the United States
item.media:description: Mink had tested positive for coronavirus in Spain and the Netherlands, before the first cases were confirmed in the U.S.

item.title: Kristin Urquiza, Whose Father Died of Covid, Denounces Trump at D.N.C.
item.description: Ms. Urquiza, whose impassioned obituary drew national attention, said her father’s “only pre-existing condition was trusting Donald Trump — and for that he paid with his life.”
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens, Isabella Grullón Paz and Jennifer Medina

item.title: Democrats Begin Virtual Convention, Hailing Biden and Denouncing Trump
item.description: Driven online because of the coronavirus, the program spanned the ideological gamut, from socialists to Republicans. “Donald Trump is the wrong president for our country,” Michelle Obama said.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Officials’ Attempt to End Transgender Health Protections
item.description: The decision arrived a day before a Trump administration rule narrowing the legal definition of sex discrimination was set to take effect.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz and Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal judge in New York found that the Trump administration’s rule appeared to be incompatible with a Supreme Court case establishing that employers cannot discriminate against transgender people in the workplace.

item.title: A Call to Rally Around Joe Biden ‘Like Our Lives Depend on It’
item.description: Everyone at the first night of the Democrats’ virtual gathering could at least agree that Mr. Biden should be the next president. They can worry about the rest later.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Sydney Ember
item.media:description: The desire to beat President Trump cut across ideological and generational lines.

item.title: Barack Obama tweets his convention soundtrack.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama’s summer playlist features music that spans genres.

item.title: DeJoy Earned Millions From Company With Financial Ties to Postal Service
item.description: The postmaster general, under fire for his business ties and his cost-cutting measures, will testify before the House next week.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats say that policy changes have caused a slowdown in mail delivery and could imperil mail-in voting in November.
